text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with easy Cheese Souffle that's

right any time I can eliminate a step
from a classic recipe and it ends up

coming out just as good I'm always
extremely happy and thrilled but when we

can actually eliminate a step and the
recipe comes out better that is a very

rare and special occasion indeed and by
the way this technique is gonna work

whether you're making a savory cheese
souffle or something a little bit

sweeter you're gonna serve for dessert
which by the way is the style we're

doing and because of that the first step
here is going to be the butter and sugar

some ramekins and not surprisingly that
will begin by melting some butter and

brushing it all over the inside and I'm
not sure how but actually remember from

culinary school they told us when we
brushed always brush up the sides of the

ramekin since that will help the souffle
rise straight which could be true I'm

not sure I've never tried it both ways
and compared but you know what it's one

of those things that sounds like it
could be true which is good enough for

me and then what we'll do once those
have been severely buttered just go

ahead and scoop in some sugar and then
sort of turn the ramekin round like this

letting the excess fall out as we do and
as you'll see after a few rotations that

ramekin should be successfully sugared
and that is pretty much it for the prep

on that well simply place those on some
kind of baking sheet and move on to our

new and exciting and incredibly simple
soufflé batter which like all soufflé

batter starts by separating some eggs
and for me the funnest and easiest way

to do this is through the fingers just
simply crack that egg in your hand and

we'll let that white slip between our
fingers into One Bowl and transfer the

yolk into the other and while it's
totally fine to get a little bit of that

white in the yolk bowl please try not to
get any yolk into the bowl of whites

since that's gonna make whipping them up
much harder but anyway we're gonna

separate two large eggs and we'll set
the whites aside for now and start with

the yolks to which we will add some
white sugar as well as some all-purpose

flour we will also want a little pinch
of salt as well as a few drops of

everybody's favorite extract vanilla and
then we'll continue on with a little bit

of freshly grated lemon zest which
brings us to our cheeses and we're going

to do two different kinds the first of
which would be some cream cheese

and yes I'm using the fancy stuff which
is slightly drier but any Brad should

work and I'm also going to toss in some
grated cheddar cheese although any other

kind of grating cheese would work and
I'll give you some options on the blog

post and then what we'll do is take a
spatula and mix this smooth or at least

until all the sugar and flour disappear
and believe it or not that's gonna be it

for our souffle base and by the way if
you're wondering what steps we've cut

out of the traditional method it's
pretty much all of them since usually

you have to make a roux first and then a
white sauce and then a cheese sauce and

then let it cool and then add your egg
yolks and the rest of the flavorings so

this really is quite a simplified method
so like I said we'll go ahead and mix

that up and I said smooth even though
it's really not smooth since those

little things that look like lumps are
actually the grated cheddar so basically

we're just going to mix that into like I
said the flour and sugar disappear at

which point we'll set that aside and
move on to the second component of every

souffle the whipped egg whites and for
those all we have to do is toss in a

pinch of salt which is a little bit for
seasoning but it also helps say whites

whip up a little bit better as does by
the way room-temperature egg whites so

it's good we left these sitting out for
a while and what we'll want to do is

whip these until peaks form
but not overly stiff peaks all right we

want Peaks that hold their shape but
don't get all dry and grainy oh by the

way many souffle recipes add extra white
here so you get nice high souffles but

I'm not a fan of that because while yes
the souffle does come out higher and

possibly more impressive visually those
extra whites are actually gonna dilute

the flavor okay air bubbles are
tasteless so I'm always gonna choose

flavor overinflation but anyway no
matter how many egg whites you use we're

gonna keep whisking and whisking and in
a surprisingly short amount of time you

should have some nice beautiful Peaks
that look something like this right you

see that they hold their shape nicely
but nice to find edges but they're not

too stiff and all dry and grainy looking
so these are looking just about perfect

and once those are sat we're ready to
take a spatula and merge our two

components and the way that's done is by
adding about half of our egg whites to

our base and we'll sort of fold / stir
that in and this first edition is

basically just to lighten the batter
so we don't have to be too too gentle

which is why we're stirring and folding
because what's gonna happen once that

first half is incorporated and our
batter has been beautifully lightened

we'll go ahead and add the other half of
the whites and then gently fold them in

and by fold we simply mean going
underneath or along the side and bring

us some of that batter up and over the
top and we'll continue doing that until

95% of those whites have been mixed in
okay because a little bits gonna mix in

as we transfer this into the ramekins so
we'll continue gently and thoughtfully

folding those whites in until our
mixture looks something like this

and then once that's been accomplished
we'll go ahead and carefully transfer

that into our ramekins and ideally we're
filling these up just to where that lip

starts around the top although if you
did a better job of folding your whites

in than I did
and you have a little extra batter you

could probably go ahead and fill these
up a little higher and see what happens

and then once our batter is transferred
in some people like to create some

cheese on top but I don't I guess I'm
afraid of the extra weight but if you

want to add some go ahead I mean you are
after all the HR Pufnstuf of stuff that

puffs but either way once those are
filled extra cheese or not they are

ready to transfer into the center of a
400 degree oven for about 12 minutes or

so or until beautifully puffed and
browned and looking a little something

like this check it out and as with all
souffles if you want the oohs and ahhs

from your guests make sure they're in
the kitchen when these come out because

they do deflate relatively quickly and
also you really do want to serve these

right away all right if you let them sit
around while you take a bunch of

pictures like I did they actually will
continue to cook in that hot ramekin

although as you're about to see mine
we're still pretty good and by pretty

good I mean awesome so let me grab a
spoon and dig in oops

there we go and ultimately what we're
trying to achieve here is something that

has a feather-light texture while still
maintaining an intense non diluted

cheesy flavor and that's exactly what
I'm enjoying here okay I can barely feel

any weight on that spoon and yet that
punch of flavor is that of something

much more dense and much heavier and
since we didn't use a roux based white

sauce I think those flavors come through
even more pronounced so like I said in

the intro even though we cut out a step
or two I believe the final products even

the nutritional method so this really
did come out quite well even though

according to the French we horribly
overcook this and that's because it's

totally set and none of the batter is
still runny all right one of my favorite

all-time French food sayings is that it
properly prepared souffle makes its own

sauce all right so here's one we cooked
a minute less as well as we'll serve

right away without letting it sit and
what happens when you intentionally

undercook achieve souffle a little bit a
certain percentage of the batter stays

liquefied and basically acts as a
delicious delicious cheese sauce and by

the way if you're wondering if this is
safe I sure hope so a lot of people

watch these videos but according to a
couple thousand years of anecdotal

evidence from France you should be fine
and even though I showed you the non

French version first to me this is
really the way you want to enjoy this oh

don't get me wrong it's great the other
way it's just not quite as mind-blowing

that if you make it this way so
incredibly simple recipe and technique

but I do want you to play around a
little bit with baking times to dial in

that perfect perfect texture for your
personal tastes but anyway that's it my

new and improved method for making
cheese souffle it's faster it's easier

and it tastes better but other than that
no major improvements so I really do

hope you give this a try soon head over
to food wishes calm for all the

ingredient amounts of more info as usual
and as always enjoy
you
